title: How to Make Lemon Balm Tea

steps.headline: Select good quality lemon balm leaves.
steps.description: Choose the green leaves without blemish or dry parts. Separate the thick stalks from the leaves by pulling off the leaves––small stalks can be left in place if still intact after pulling away leaves.

steps.headline: Rinse the lemon balm leaves.
steps.description: Remove any soil or other debris on the leaves. Shake to remove excess moisture.

steps.headline: Boil the water.
steps.description: Boil a fresh kettle of water, then have ready for pouring.

steps.headline: Prepare a teapot for pouring in water.
steps.description: Before adding the water, warm the pot first by filling with hot water from the tap, swishing it around, then pouring out. Then place the lemon balm leaves into the teapot and fill the teapot with the water. If you don't have a teapot for infusing, use a heatproof jug or similar container.

steps.headline: Allow to infuse.
steps.description: For the best flavor, infuse for 10 minutes, with 5 minutes minimum. To reduce heat dissipation, keep the teapot placed on a cork or wooden base and make sure the lid is on top.

steps.headline: Strain and pour.
steps.description: Pour through a tea strainer into 2 cups or mugs for serving, pouring even amounts. If you want to sweeten, add a little clear honey or lemon juice. Optional but a nice touch: Add a fresh sprig of lemon balm leaves for garnish.

steps.headline: Use fresh dried leaves.
steps.description: The leaves should be under 6 months old from the time of drying, to ensure best flavor. You can either purchase dried leaves from a reliable supplier or pick your own and dry them.

steps.headline: Boil the water.
steps.description: Boil the kettle with the measured amount of water. Set aside in readiness for pouring.

steps.headline: Place the leaves into a warmed teapot for infusing.
steps.description: A glass teapot is ideal because it is enjoyable to watch the leaves unfurl in the water. To stop it from cooling down too fast, rest on cork or wood and make sure the lid is on top. To warm the teapot, fill with hot tap water, swish around, then pour out.

steps.headline: Pour the boiled water into the teapot.
Pour and strain.
steps.description: Strain through a tea strainer into 2 cups or mugs for serving. To serve, you can serve as it is or sweeten with clear honey or lemon juice.

text: Dried Lemon Balm Tea Select good quality lemon balm leaves. Choose the green leaves without blemish or dry parts. Separate the thick stalks from the leaves by pulling off the leaves––small stalks can be left in place if still intact after pulling away leaves. Rinse the lemon balm leaves. Remove any soil or other debris on the leaves. Shake to remove excess moisture. Boil the water. Boil a fresh kettle of water, then have ready for pouring. Prepare a teapot for pouring in water. Before adding the water, warm the pot first by filling with hot water from the tap, swishing it around, then pouring out. Then place the lemon balm leaves into the teapot and fill the teapot with the water. If you don't have a teapot for infusing, use a heatproof jug or similar container. Allow to infuse. For the best flavor, infuse for 10 minutes, with 5 minutes minimum. To reduce heat dissipation, keep the teapot placed on a cork or wooden base and make sure the lid is on top. Strain and pour. Pour through a tea strainer into 2 cups or mugs for serving, pouring even amounts. If you want to sweeten, add a little clear honey or lemon juice. Optional but a nice touch: Add a fresh sprig of lemon balm leaves for garnish. Dried Lemon Balm Tea Use fresh dried leaves. The leaves should be under 6 months old from the time of drying, to ensure best flavor. You can either purchase dried leaves from a reliable supplier or pick your own and dry them. Boil the water. Boil the kettle with the measured amount of water. Set aside in readiness for pouring. Place the leaves into a warmed teapot for infusing. A glass teapot is ideal because it is enjoyable to watch the leaves unfurl in the water. To stop it from cooling down too fast, rest on cork or wood and make sure the lid is on top. To warm the teapot, fill with hot tap water, swish around, then pour out. Pour the boiled water into the teapot. Steep for 5 to 10 minutes. Pour and strain. Strain through a tea strainer into 2 cups or mugs for serving. To serve, you can serve as it is or sweeten with clear honey or lemon juice.
